page.title: 18Meadowland birds in Fulford
page.content: The pheasant is common in Fulford.They are bred by farmers as game birds but have established themselves in the wild.They feed on corn,turnips, worms, acorns, insects and beetles. Nests are found on the ground, in hedge bottoms and undergrowth. The wood pigeon is regarded as a pest by local farmers as large flocks eat the corn.It nests in high trees where it cannot be attacked by predators.The magpie,an attractive bird, steals eggs and fledglings from small birds. Its nest is domed and is usually found in small trees. Although seen in gardens it is more frequently seen on farmland in the area. The kestrel is a commom bird of prey which likes to hunt near the A64 and A19 where small rodents are aroused. Occasionally it takes worms, small birds and young rabbits.
